Or add the following line to your Cargo.toml:
httptest = "0.16.3"

# httptest
[](https://crates.io/crates/httptest) [![](https://img.gs/czjpqfbdkz/full/https://docs.rs/httptest/badge.svg)](https://docs.rs/httptest)
Provide convenient mechanism for testing http clients against a locally running http server. The typical usage is as follows:
  * Start a server
  * Configure the server by adding expectations
  * Test your http client by making requests to the server
  * On Drop the server verifies all expectations were met.


## Example Test
```
```#``[``tokio`::`test``]``
async ``fn` `test_readme`````(````)``````{`
  `use` `http_body_util`::```{`BodyExt`,` Full`}``;`
  `use` `httptest`::```{``matchers`::```*``,` `responders`::```*``,` Expectation`,` Server`}``;`
  `use` `hyper_util`::```client`::```legacy`::``Client`;`
  `use` `serde_json`::``json`;`
  ``//` Starting a logger within the test can make debugging a failed test`
  ``//` easier. The mock http server will log::debug every request and response`
  ``//` received along with what, if any, matcher was found for the request. When`
  ``//` env_logger is initialized running the test with `RUST_LOG=httptest=debug`
  ``//` cargo test` can provide that information on stderr.`
  `let` `_` `=` `pretty_env_logger`::``try_init`(``)``;`
  ``//` Start a server running on a local ephemeral port.`
  `let` server `=` `Server`::``run`(``)``;`
  ``//` Configure the server to expect a single GET /foo request and respond`
  ``//` with a 200 status code.`
  server`.``expect``(`
    `Expectation`::``matching`(``request`::``method_path`(```"`GET`"```,` ``"`/foo`"```)``)``.``respond_with``(``status_code``(``200``)``)``,`
  `)``;`
  ``//` Configure the server to also receive between 1 and 3 POST /bar requests`
  ``//` with a json body matching {'foo': 'bar'}, and respond with a json body`
  ``//` {'result': 'success'}`
  server`.``expect``(`
    `Expectation`::``matching`(``all_of!``[`
      `request`::``method`(```"`POST`"```)``,`
      `request`::``path`(```"`/bar`"```)``,`
      `request`::``body`(``json_decoded``(``eq``(``json!``(``{```"`foo`"```:` ``"`bar`"```}``)``)``)``)``,`
    `]``)`
    `.``times``(``1``..``=``3``)`
    `.``respond_with``(``json_encoded``(``json!``(``{```"`result`"```:` ``"`success`"```}``)``)``)``,`
  `)``;`
  ``//` The server provides server.addr() that returns the address of the`
  ``//` locally running server, or more conveniently provides a server.url()`
  ``//` method that gives a fully formed http url to the provided path.`
  `let` url `=` server`.``url``(```"`/foo`"```)``;`
  ``//` Now test your http client against the server.`
  `let` client `=` `Client`::``builder`(``hyper_util`::```rt`::```TokioExecutor`::``new`(``)``)`
    `.``build_http`::````<`Full`<``hyper`::```body`::``Bytes`>``>```(``)``;`
  ``//` Issue the GET /foo to the server.`
  `let` resp `=` client`.``get``(`url`)``.`await`.``unwrap``(``)``;`
  ``//` Optionally use response matchers to assert the server responded as`
  ``//` expected.`
  ``//` Assert the response was a 200.`
  `assert_eq!``(``200``,` resp`.``status``(``)``.``as_u16``(``)``)``;`
  ``//` Issue a POST /bar with {'foo': 'bar'} json body.`
  `let` post_req `=` `http`::```Request`::``post`(`server`.``url``(```"`/bar`"```)``)`
    `.``body``(``json!``(``{```"`foo`"```:` ``"`bar`"```}``)``.``to_string``(``)``.``into``(``)``)`
    `.``unwrap``(``)``;`
  `let` resp `=` client`.``request``(`post_req`)``.`await`.``unwrap``(``)``;`
  ``//` Assert the response was a 200 with a json body of {'result': 'success'}`
  `assert_eq!``(``200``,` resp`.``status``(``)``.``as_u16``(``)``)``;`
  ``//` Read the entire response body into a Vec<u8> to allow using the body`
  ``//` response matcher.`
  `let` body `=` resp`.``collect``(``)``.`await`.``unwrap``(``)``.``to_bytes``(``)``;`
  `assert_eq!``(`
    `json!``(``{```"`result`"```:` ``"`success`"```}``)``,`
    `serde_json`::```from_slice`::````<``serde_json`::``Value`>```(``&`body`)``.``unwrap``(``)`
  `)``;`
  ``//` on Drop the server will assert all expectations have been met and will`
  ``//` panic if not.`
```}```
`
```

#### Dependencies
~10–21MB  ~291K SLoC
  * [bstr](https://lib.rs/crates/bstr "1.9.1")
  * [bytes](https://lib.rs/crates/bytes "1.6")
  * [crossbeam-channel](https://lib.rs/crates/crossbeam-channel "0.5.12")
  * [form_urlencoded](https://lib.rs/crates/form_urlencoded "1.2")
  * [futures](https://lib.rs/crates/futures "0.3")[+std](https://lib.rs/crates/futures/features#feature-std)[+async-await](https://lib.rs/crates/futures/features#feature-async-await)
  * [http](https://lib.rs/crates/http "new") 1.1
  * [http-body-util](https://lib.rs/crates/http-body-util "0.1")
  * [hyper](https://lib.rs/crates/hyper "new") 1.2[+http1](https://lib.rs/crates/hyper/features#feature-http1)[+http2](https://lib.rs/crates/hyper/features#feature-http2)[+server](https://lib.rs/crates/hyper/features#feature-server)
  * [hyper-util](https://lib.rs/crates/hyper-util "0.1")[+http1](https://lib.rs/crates/hyper-util/features#feature-http1)[+http2](https://lib.rs/crates/hyper-util/features#feature-http2)[+server](https://lib.rs/crates/hyper-util/features#feature-server)[+tokio](https://lib.rs/crates/hyper-util/features#feature-tokio)
  * [log](https://lib.rs/crates/log "0.4.21")
  * [once_cell](https://lib.rs/crates/once_cell "1.19.0")
  * [regex](https://lib.rs/crates/regex "1.10.4")
  * [serde](https://lib.rs/crates/serde "1")
  * [serde_json](https://lib.rs/crates/serde_json "1.0")
  * [serde_urlencoded](https://lib.rs/crates/serde_urlencoded "0.7")
  * [tokio](https://lib.rs/crates/tokio "1.37")[+macros](https://lib.rs/crates/tokio/features#feature-macros)[+rt-multi-thread](https://lib.rs/crates/tokio/features#feature-rt-multi-thread)[+time](https://lib.rs/crates/tokio/features#feature-time)


  * dev  [crossbeam-utils](https://lib.rs/crates/crossbeam-utils "0.8.19")
  * dev  [pretty_env_logger](https://lib.rs/crates/pretty_env_logger "new") 0.5


  *[SLoC]: approx. additional lines of code

# httptest
[](https://crates.io/crates/httptest) ![⟨4⟩](https://docs.rs/httptest)
Provide convenient mechanism for testing http clients against a locally running http server. The typical usage is as follows:
  * Start a server
  * Configure the server by adding expectations
  * Test your http client by making requests to the server
  * On Drop the server verifies all expectations were met.


## Example Test
```
```#``[``tokio`::`test``]``
async ``fn` `test_readme`````(````)``````{`
  `use` `http_body_util`::```{`BodyExt`,` Full`}``;`
  `use` `httptest`::```{``matchers`::```*``,` `responders`::```*``,` Expectation`,` Server`}``;`
  `use` `hyper_util`::```client`::```legacy`::``Client`;`
  `use` `serde_json`::``json`;`

  ``//` received along with what, if any, matcher was found for the request. When`
  ``//` env_logger is initialized running the test with `RUST_LOG=httptest=debug`
  ``//` cargo test` can provide that information on stderr.`

  ``//` Start a server running on a local ephemeral port.`
  `let` server `=` `Server`::``run`(``)``;`
  ``//` Configure the server to expect a single GET /foo request and respond`
  ``//` with a 200 status code.`
  server`.``expect``(`
    `Expectation`::``matching`(``request`::``method_path`(```"`GET`"```,` ``"`/foo`"```)``)``.``respond_with``(``status_code``(``200``)``)``,`
  `)``;`
  ``//` Configure the server to also receive between 1 and 3 POST /bar requests`
  ``//` with a json body matching {'foo': 'bar'}, and respond with a json body`
  ``//` {'result': 'success'}`
  server`.``expect``(`
    `Expectation`::``matching`(``all_of!``[`
      `request`::``method`(```"`POST`"```)``,`
      `request`::``path`(```"`/bar`"```)``,`
      `request`::``body`(``json_decoded``(``eq``(``json!``(``{```"`foo`"```:` ``"`bar`"```}``)``)``)``)``,`
    `]``)`
    `.``times``(``1``..``=``3``)`
    `.``respond_with``(``json_encoded``(``json!``(``{```"`result`"```:` ``"`success`"```}``)``)``)``,`
  `)``;`
  ``//` The server provides server.addr() that returns the address of the`
  ``//` locally running server, or more conveniently provides a server.url()`
  ``//` method that gives a fully formed http url to the provided path.`

  ``//` Now test your http client against the server.`
  `let` client `=` `Client`::``builder`(``hyper_util`::```rt`::```TokioExecutor`::``new`(``)``)`
    `.``build_http`::````<`Full`<``hyper`::```body`::``Bytes`>``>```(``)``;`
  ``//` Issue the GET /foo to the server.`
  `let` resp `=` client`.``get``(`url`)``.`await`.``unwrap``(``)``;`
  ``//` Optionally use response matchers to assert the server responded as`
  ``//` expected.`
  ``//` Assert the response was a 200.`
  `assert_eq!``(``200``,` resp`.``status``(``)``.``as_u16``(``)``)``;`
  ``//` Issue a POST /bar with {'foo': 'bar'} json body.`
  `let` post_req `=` `http`::```Request`::``post`(`server`.``url``(```"`/bar`"```)``)`
    `.``body``(``json!``(``{```"`foo`"```:` ``"`bar`"```}``)``.``to_string``(``)``.``into``(``)``)`
    `.``unwrap``(``)``;`

  ``//` Assert the response was a 200 with a json body of {'result': 'success'}`

  ``//` Read the entire response body into a Vec<u8> to allow using the body`
  ``//` response matcher.`

  `assert_eq!``(`
    `json!``(``{```"`result`"```:` ``"`success`"```}``)``,`
    `serde_json`::```from_slice`::````<``serde_json`::``Value`>```(``&`body`)``.``unwrap``(``)`
  `)``;`
  ``//` on Drop the server will assert all expectations have been met and will`
  ``//` panic if not.`
```}```

content.references_markdown:
## References

⟨1⟩ https://lib.rs/crates/httptest/versions: 44 releases
⟨2⟩ https://lib.rs/web-programming/http-server: Crates to serve data over HTTP. - HTTP server
⟨3⟩ https://lib.rs/crates/httptest/rev:  **37** crates
⟨4⟩ https://img.gs/czjpqfbdkz/full/https://docs.rs/httptest/badge.svg: ![
⟨5⟩ https://lib.rs/crates/bstr: 1.9.1 - bstr
⟨6⟩ https://lib.rs/crates/bytes: 1.6 - bytes
⟨7⟩ https://lib.rs/crates/crossbeam-channel: 0.5.12 - crossbeam-channel
⟨8⟩ https://lib.rs/crates/form_urlencoded: 1.2 - form_urlencoded
⟨9⟩ https://lib.rs/crates/futures: 0.3 - futures

enriched_crate.readme_summary: The `httptest` crate provides a convenient way to test HTTP clients by simulating a local HTTP server with configurable expectations and responses. It supports request matching, response customization (e.g., status codes, headers, and bodies), and automatic verification of expectations on server drop. Additionally, it offers server pooling to limit concurrent servers for resource efficiency in large test suites.
enriched_crate.factual_counterfactual:
### Pair 1: Server Behavior and Expectations
✅ **Factual**: The `httptest` crate ensures that all expectations configured for a server are verified either on `Drop` or when `Server::verify_and_clear` is explicitly invoked. This guarantees that no expectation is left unchecked during the test lifecycle.  
❌ **Counterfactual**: The `httptest` crate automatically clears all expectations after each incoming request, ensuring no leftover expectations remain for subsequent requests.

---

### Pair 2: ServerPool Concurrency
✅ **Factual**: The `ServerPool` feature in `httptest` allows limiting the number of concurrently running HTTP mock servers, effectively restricting test suite concurrency to the maximum number of servers defined in the pool.  
❌ **Counterfactual**: The `ServerPool` feature in `httptest` dynamically scales the number of servers based on the number of tests being executed, allowing unlimited concurrency without blocking.

---

### Pair 3: Response Customization
✅ **Factual**: The `httptest` crate provides responder utilities such as `status_code`, `json_encoded`, and `url_encoded`, enabling developers to configure HTTP responses with custom status codes, headers, and body content.  
❌ **Counterfactual**: The `httptest` crate only supports static response configurations with predefined status codes and does not allow dynamic response customization based on request properties.
